sections.learning methods based on functional map:
In contrast to axiomatic approaches that use handcrafted features, a variety of methods have been proposed to learn the feature descriptors directly from data. Starting from , the (supervised) FMNet was proposed to learn a non-linear transformation of SHOT descriptors [ref]40. Later work  modified the loss to enable FMNet training in an unsupervised manner. However, both methods compute a loss that relies on geodesic distances, which is computationally expensive, particularly for high-resolution shapes. SURFMNet  proposed an unsupervised loss based on functional map regularisation, which, however, does not directly obtain point-to-point correspondences.
More recently, several works  [ref]41 replaced FMNet with point-based networks   to achieve better performance. However, such point-based networks cannot utilise the connectivity information that exists in triangle meshes. To make use of it, DiffusionNet  introduced a diffusion layer, which was shown to achieve state-of-the-art performance for 3D shape matching. Most recently, DPFM  extended DiffusionNet with a cross-attention refinement mechanism [ref]47 for partial shape matching.
DPFM addresses two variants of partial matching problems: for partial-to-partial matching it relies on a supervised training strategy, and for partial-to-complete matching it can be trained in an unsupervised manner based on functional map regularisation  5. While DPFM predicts functional maps and thereby requires a post-processing to obtain point-wise maps, our proposed approach directly predicts point-wise maps without the need of computing functional maps during inference.
